title: Cat. 134  Jar, 3rd/4th century A.D.
publication_title: Roman Art at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Jar  
3rd/4th century A.D.  
Late Roman or early Byzantine, coast of Syria or Palestine  
Glass, blown; h. 6.4 cm (2 1/2 in.); diam. 6.2 cm (2 7/16 in.)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Theodore W. and Frances S. Robinson, 1949.1129

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">Transparent amethyst and colorless glass with a brown tinge. Blown, trail decorated, and tooled. The rounded rim tapers to a solid horizontal rib forming a vertical collared rim then constricts to create a short, inward-tapering neck. The neck spreads out into a globular body with a flattened base that retains a pontil mark. A trail of colorless glass with a brown tinge is pulled up and down from shoulder to rim ten times. For a zoomable image, see fig. 134.1.

The vessel is unweathered with a small chip in the rim and a segment of missing trail.

This color was a favorite of late Roman glassblowers along the Syro-Palestinian coast, but it must have been a more expensive jar, as amethyst glass was usually employed only as a highlight. Many more examples in the typical transparent olive-green to greenish-blue glasses are known.

The jar and its applied shoulder decoration are well-known at sites along the Syro-Palestinian coast. The color combination is more unusual. There are examples in the Princeton University Art Museum, in one of which the colors are reversed: the vessel is light green and the zigzag decoration is amethyst glass. A jar fashioned entirely of amethyst glass is in the Newark Museum, and a similar one was recently offered on the American market.  
Sidney Goldstein

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Crowfoot, Crawfoot, and Kenyon, Objects from Samaria, p. 413, no. 17, fig. 95. There are other examples from tombs at other sites: for Jerusalem, see Bagatti and Milik, Gli scavi del “Dominus Flevit,” p. 148, nos. 7–8, fig. 35; for Megiddo, see Guy and Engberg, Megiddo Tombs, p. 129, pl. 175, no. 6, an example with horizontal trail decoration on the body as well as the zigzag trail from shoulder to rim.

Antonaras, Fire and Sand, p. 205, no. 302, a jar of light-green glass with an amethyst zigzag trail on the shoulder, and references; p. 203, no. 299, a small amethyst jar of similar profile but with attached multiple handles rather than a zigzag decoration.

Auth, Ancient Glass in the Newark Museum, p. 141, no. 178, with horizontal trails on the body.

Fortuna Fine Arts, Solid Liquid, p. 96, no. 177; no. 178 is the same form fashioned entirely of pale-green glass.

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 134 Jar, 3rd/4th century A.D.

fig. 134.1 Jar (3rd/4th century A.D.). The Art Institute of Chicago, 1949.1129. Zoomable image.

</section>
